TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi serializable sealed FileAttributes extends System.Enum

Docs.summary: Provides attributes for files and directories.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can get attributes for files and directories by calling the <xref:System.IO.File.GetAttributes%2A> method, and you can set them by calling the <xref:System.IO.File.SetAttributes%2A> method.
It is not possible to change the compression status of a <xref:System.IO.File> object by using the <xref:System.IO.File.SetAttributes%2A> method. Instead, you must actually compress the file using either a compression tool or one of the classes in the <xref:System.IO.Compression?displayProperty=fullName> namespace.
## Examples The following example shows how to retrieve the attributes for a file and check if the file is read-only.
[!code-vb[System.IO.FileAttributes#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.io.fileattributes_1.vb)] [!code-cs[System.IO.FileAttributes#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.io.fileattributes_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes Archive = int32(32)

Docs.summary: The file is a candidate for backup or removal.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes Compressed = int32(2048)
.field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes Device = int32(64)
.field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes Directory = int32(16)
.field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes Encrypted = int32(16384)

Docs.summary: The file or directory is encrypted. For a file, this means that all data in the file is encrypted. For a directory, this means that encryption is the default for newly created files and directories.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes Hidden = int32(2)

Docs.summary: The file is hidden, and thus is not included in an ordinary directory listing.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes IntegrityStream = int32(32768)

Docs.summary: The file or directory includes data integrity support. When this value is applied to a file, all data streams in the file have integrity support. When this value is applied to a directory, all new files and subdirectories within that directory, by default, include integrity support.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes Normal = int32(128)

Docs.summary: The file is a standard file that has no special attributes. This attribute is valid only if it is used alone.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes NoScrubData = int32(131072)

Docs.summary: The file or directory is excluded from the data integrity scan. When this value is applied to a directory, by default, all new files and subdirectories within that directory are excluded from data integrity.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes NotContentIndexed = int32(8192)

Docs.summary: The file will not be indexed by the operating system's content indexing service.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes Offline = int32(4096)

Docs.summary: The file is offline. The data of the file is not immediately available.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes ReadOnly = int32(1)
.field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes ReparsePoint = int32(1024)

Docs.summary: The file contains a reparse point, which is a block of user-defined data associated with a file or a directory.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes SparseFile = int32(512)

Docs.summary: The file is a sparse file. Sparse files are typically large files whose data consists of mostly zeros.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes System = int32(4)

Docs.summary: The file is a system file. That is, the file is part of the operating system or is used exclusively by the operating system.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static literal valuetype System.IO.FileAttributes Temporary = int32(256)

Docs.summary: The file is temporary. A temporary file contains data that is needed while an application is executing but is not needed after the application is finished. File systems try to keep all the data in memory for quicker access rather than flushing the data back to mass storage. A temporary file should be deleted by the application as soon as it is no longer needed.
